sections.summary: Allah introduces the **Quran** as a detailed revelation in Arabic intended for people of knowledge. However, many turn away, claiming their hearts are screened and their ears are deafened by a self-imposed **barrier** against the message.

The Prophet is identified as a mortal man who receives inspiration concerning **Divine Oneness**, urging humanity to seek forgiveness from their Lord. A warning is issued to idolaters who reject **charity** and the Hereafter, while the faithful are promised an uninterrupted reward.

This section details the creation of the earth in two days and the establishment of its **provisions** and stabilizers in four days [569–570]. Allah commanded the smoke of the sky to form seven universes in two days, completing the design of the **Almighty**.

A warning is given regarding a **thunderbolt** similar to the one that struck the nations of Aad and Thamood for their arrogance and rejection of messengers. While Aad prided themselves on their physical power, Thamood preferred spiritual **blindness** over the guidance provided to them [570–571].

On the Day of Judgment, the **hearing, sight, and skins** of the guilty will testify against them regarding their worldly deeds. Allah, who grants speech to all things, will return humanity to Himself for a final reckoning of their **ruinous thoughts**.

Disbelievers seek to drown out the Quran with noise, leading to an intense recompense in the **Fire** where they will wish to trample those who misled them [571–572]. Conversely, those who remain steadfast in their faith receive **angelic support** and the promise of eternal hospitality in the Garden.

The most excellent speech is defined as inviting others to Allah while acting with **integrity**. Believers are instructed to repel evil with what is better to transform enemies into friends and to seek refuge in Allah from **Satanic temptation**.

Natural phenomena like the night, day, sun, and moon are presented as signs that demand the worship of the **Creator** rather than the creation. Those who despise divine revelations are reminded that their actions are never hidden from the **Seeing**.

The Quran is described as an **invincible Book** that falsehood cannot approach from any direction. As a revelation in Arabic, it serves as both **guidance and healing** for those who believe, though it remains a source of deafness for those who refuse to listen.

Allah affirms that every individual is responsible for their own conduct, with **righteousness** benefiting the soul and evil harming it. Knowledge of the **Hour** is reserved for Him alone, and on that Day, all associated partners will vanish, leaving the guilty with no escape.

Humanity is characterized by a tendency to tire of praying for good while falling into **despair** during adversity [573–574]. When favored with mercy, man often becomes distracted by **vanity** and distances himself from the Lord until he is again touched by hardship.

Allah promises to manifest His proofs on the **horizons** and within human souls until the Truth of the revelation becomes undeniable. The surah concludes by affirming that Allah **comprehends everything** and is a sufficient witness over all creation.
